docs.abstract: The in-room relaxation offerings are well-suited to the times, one expert said, because they limit contact with others yet provide a wellness experience.
docs.snippet: The in-room relaxation offerings are well-suited to the times, one expert said, because they limit contact with others yet provide a wellness experience.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hotels have always been in the business of providing a good night’s rest, but a growing number of brands are adding tools to help guests chill out and get to sleep.

headline.main: Hotels Were Rolling Out Tools to Help Calm Travelers. Then Coronavirus Hit.

docs.abstract: Let’s say you’ve downsized from a larger place. Here’s what to consider before you commit.
docs.snippet: Let’s say you’ve downsized from a larger place. Here’s what to consider before you commit.
docs.lead_paragraph: In 2015, after her husband died, Merrily Hardisty decided she no longer needed the space or the maintenance hassles of their four-bedroom house in Bethesda, Md., a Washington suburb. Like many older people who downsize, Ms. Hardisty faced another decision: Should she buy a new place or rent one?

headline.main: You’re Retired. Should You Rent or Buy Your Home?
headline.print_headline: How to Solve the Rent-or-Buy Puzzle

docs.abstract: Led by Morgan Stanley, which borrowed from the Fed’s so-called discount window on Monday, seven other firms will follow.
docs.snippet: Led by Morgan Stanley, which borrowed from the Fed’s so-called discount window on Monday, seven other firms will follow.
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight major financial-services firms are borrowing money from the Federal Reserve, a day after the central bank urged them to tap its short-term funding facility to make it easier for credit to continue flowing through the economy, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to roil markets.

headline.main: As Market Convulses, Big Banks Plan to Borrow Funds From Fed

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

byline.original: By Kate Kelly, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jeanna Smialek

docs.abstract: “That’s what local papers are meant to do”: The journalists at The Seattle Times have been aggressively covering the coronavirus as it affects their neighbors and friends.
docs.snippet: “That’s what local papers are meant to do”: The journalists at The Seattle Times have been aggressively covering the coronavirus as it affects their neighbors and friends.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It was supposed to be a quiet Saturday.

headline.main: The Newsroom at the Center of a Pandemic
headline.print_headline: The Seattle Times Got the Scoop and Kept Its Staff Healthy

docs.abstract: A decade after the recession hit hard, Arizona’s economy is a magnet for technology companies and for workers seeking an affordable middle-class life.
docs.snippet: A decade after the recession hit hard, Arizona’s economy is a magnet for technology companies and for workers seeking an affordable middle-class life.
docs.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Colin Jordan, a 32-year-old software salesman, lists various predictable reasons for his move to Scottsdale from the San Francisco Bay Area. He likes sun and golf and lower income taxes. But beneath all that is something bigger, which is the feeling that Arizona has welcomed him in ways that California — where he grew up — did not.

headline.main: Arizona Boom Draws Californians and Changes Political Hue

docs.abstract: The Biden-Sanders matchup attracted 10.8 million viewers, down from prior forums in Nevada and South Carolina.
docs.snippet: The Biden-Sanders matchup attracted 10.8 million viewers, down from prior forums in Nevada and South Carolina.
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite tens of millions of Americans hunkering down in their homes because of the coronavirus pandemic, the CNN debate on Sunday between Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders attracted a smaller live audience than the last two Democratic matchups.

headline.main: A Drop in TV Ratings for a Democratic Debate Praised for Its Substance

docs.abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
docs.snippet: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

docs.abstract: Online enforcers are dragging in hundreds for questioning as an assault on online speech continues. They are a sign of how Beijing has given censors a more punitive role.
docs.snippet: Online enforcers are dragging in hundreds for questioning as an assault on online speech continues. They are a sign of how Beijing has given censors a more punitive role.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As China tries to reshape the narrative of its fumbled response to the coronavirus outbreak, it is turning to a new breed of police that carry out real-world reprisals for digital misdeeds.

headline.main: Coronavirus Outrage Spurs China’s Internet Police to Action
headline.print_headline: China’s Internet Police Crack Down on Outrage

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China

docs.abstract: The social network is straining to deal with skyrocketing usage as its 45,000 employees work from home for the first time.
docs.snippet: The social network is straining to deal with skyrocketing usage as its 45,000 employees work from home for the first time.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the coronavirus spread around the world and people everywhere were ordered to stay home, phone calls over Facebook’s apps more than doubled. In many countries, messaging on Instagram and Facebook soared by over 50 percent, while group calls in Italy jumped by more than 1,000 percent. And hungry for information, people clicked repeatedly on virus news stories shown by the social network.

headline.main: Facebook Is ‘Just Trying to Keep the Lights On’ as Traffic Soars in Pandemic
headline.print_headline: Traffic Soars,  And Facebook  Strains to Cope

byline.original: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

docs.abstract: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
docs.snippet: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
docs.lead_paragraph: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post on Tuesday released a statement critical of the Chinese government’s decision to bar American journalists for the three publications from working in China.

headline.main: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Decision to Expel American Journalists
headline.print_headline: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Expulsion of American Journalists
